candidates.body: This updates the rust lock files to fix the failing `cargo-deny` check

candidates.title: [hackathon] additional utilities
candidates.body:
Depends on #240


## Showing attributes

Log entries and spans, now show their attributes.
![image](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/118052430/fceba5c5-f049-4471-8d5b-ce5f195281dc)
![image](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/118052430/9a7e5840-cae3-4eff-9970-f5c96211c161)


## Span / trace error status
Inspired by how opentelemetry [supports a status](https://opentelemetry.io/docs/specs/otel/trace/api/#set-status).

Spans can now have an error status.
(When that span has *any* "log" event with `level = error`)
![image](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/118052430/25f4d388-08a5-4e0b-beb6-3aec358aba4c)

Alternatively they can be orange in the list view, if one of the child spans has an error status.
![image](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/118052430/14cc1683-c38d-4fb9-848d-2b157b97da9f)

## Detecting "kind" or known trace types ahead of time

Currently DevTools detects a set of known trace types commonly seen in Tauri apps.
It does this reactively, triggered by some of the rendering paths.

Here I've changed this to be done whenever new spans are received for a particular trace.
That trace (or root span) is marked "dirty" and detection will be run again. Avoiding a hot loop of detection by doing it per update batch. And not needing to run it for traces that have already settled and got no new data.

See `clients/web/src/lib/span/update-spans.ts` for this.

## Span details are now tree-shaped

Previously traces were shown with a list of spans.
Now they are:
- Displayed in a tree structure.
- With siblings sorted by start time.
- Colored based on error status & level (dark = debug, very dark = trace).

![image](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/118052430/265782f3-9eff-4e15-b279-bdc4aa26d66b)

## Associated logs

Logs that have a parent span will be matched against spans in this trace.
So the trace details will now show all related logs.

![image](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/118052430/1c8fb53f-938b-4bfa-acb7-f54606ccc668)

## Jump to source

When a log entry has a source reference part of your own application (e.g. not logged by a 3rd party crate).
You can jump directly to the source file by clicking on the location.

![image](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/118052430/114b9a78-2e7c-4167-88c3-762495e2dfc5)

## Jump to trace / move to parent

On the console view, you can now directly go to the span details, if it was part of a span.

![image](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/118052430/d9f36dcf-a324-44a8-b195-4218a25e02b8)

And from a particular span, you can navigate up to it's root span.

![image](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/118052430/3386d19b-9091-4e95-813b-8f7feecc0b36)

## Filtering spans

Spans can now by filtered by text. (Case sensitive though.)

![image](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/118052430/9ddd1516-01c6-4efa-bfdd-42cd312a451f)

Or by it's error status (currently includes both direct errors and child span errors).

![image](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/118052430/589394f6-3c46-4f72-a074-69f3893c80d1)

## Parsing plugin commands (new!)

Plugins have a special kind of `cmd` argument like `plugin:your_plugin|some_cmd`.
We now parse those to display in a less confusing way.

![image](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/118052430/3b5f814f-cab8-4074-bdb5-be2abed9ff3a)

Given that Tauri v2 is almost entirely based on plugins, this should be particularly helpful there.

Closes DT-153

candidates.title: fix: manually bump versions to fix release-plz release
Feat/calls virtualization
candidates.body:
# Calls virtualization

> [!Note]
> Build is currently failing on some rust license which is not important for this PR

This PR aims to reduce the load on the rendering and processing of the calls tab. It also includes some quality of life change to the calls tab.

## Why is this important ?

The calls tab shows a waterfall view that has to be updated every time a call is still running or a new call is coming in. This would mean updating the rendering of potentially hundreds or thousands of waterfalls, depending on how many calls are displayed. Thus the PR aims to reduce the amount of rendering to the actually visible calls.

Is is also important that the processing of incoming span events goes as smoothly as possible and is able to handle big chunks of updates without causing too big of a burden on the reactive system.

## Big changes

- ### Use of a [`ReactiveMap`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@solid-primitives/map) for the `MonitorData.spans` to make lookups for spans consistent
- ### Move all span processing into the `updated-spans` function to prevent the calls tab from doing further modification (this makes the state more consistent)
- ### Rename all the UI components from `spans` to `calls` (Fixes DT-52)
- ### Use of [Tanstack Virtual](https://tanstack.com/virtual/latest) to only render visible calls (and some more)


### QoL changes
- Added clear button to reset the calls view (especially important when the app idled for a while)
- Added a display for the number of calls that are being displayed in the list
- Added a display for the number of calls that are running (not closed) right now
- ![HaasGySH9Z](https://github.com/crabnebula-dev/devtools/assets/119593300/fe2d482b-0e50-4878-a5f0-ff27911bc63a)
- Added min-width to calls split panes to prevent them from crushing content (Fixes DT-97)
- Refactored structure of calls components: Mainly breaking them up into more manageable chunks and creating semantic sub folders
- Refactored calls sorting into its own file
- Moved a reference to the span metadata into the span object and refactored all the processing code accordingly
- Updated span tests
- Introduces a minimum size for calls on the waterfall to prevent them from disappearing (Fixes DT-55)


Fixed DT-113, DT-46
 

> [!Note]
> There is a problem with the instrumentation dropping some span events. This problem can be duct taped by the follwing change to the `crates/devtools-core/src/aggregator.rs`
> ```rust
>   /// Buffered log events.
>   /// Up to 512 events are retained before the oldest will be dropped.
>    logs: EventBuf<LogEvent, 512>,
>    /// Buffered span events.
>    /// Up to 2048 events are retained before the oldest will be dropped.
>    spans: EventBuf<SpanEvent, 4096>,
>```
